Award.AwardTitle: RUI: The role of aquaporin channels in the eel intestinal water influx pathway during salinity acclimation
Award.AbstractNarration: Eels migrate from rivers to the sea to breed and when they do so, one of the main challenges they face is that they must cope with the increase in salinity. In seawater, teleosts (bony fishes) lose water to the environment and in order to overcome this problem, they drink seawater. The intestine absorbs both salts and water, but the excess salts are excreted by the gills. It is not known how water absorption takes place in fish intestines and the goal of this project is to use molecular, biochemical, and physiological approaches to determine if water transport proteins, aquaporins, are involved in this process. One aspect of this project will reveal whether aquaporin proteins are in the correct location in intestinal cells to absorb the water. In addition, the functional characteristics of these proteins will be determined by expressing them in Xenopus (frog) oocytes and studying their transport characteristics. Eels will be transferred from freshwater to seawater, mimicking their natural migration, to test the hypothesis that there should be an increase the production of intestinal aquaporins that corresponds to the increased water absorption seen during acclimation to seawater. In addition, the importance of these proteins in intestinal water transport will be demonstrated by determining the rate of intestinal water transport after the levels of aquaporins are lowered by interfering with the intestinal cell's ability to synthesize these proteins. The project will not only have a major impact on understanding how fish are adapted to living in seawater, but will also increase the general level of knowledge concerning water transport processes in other animals. This project will involve the training of graduate and undergraduate students at both Georgia Southern University and Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the key characteristics of eels is that they can inhabit both freshwater (low salinity) and seawater (high salinity) environments. In freshwater, the fish's internal water and salt control mechanisms operate in a similar fashion to humans with excess water excreted in increased urine. However in seawater, eels dehydrate and need to acquire additional water to cover their losses. They have a counter-intuitive mechanism to achieve this. They drink seawater but then have to absorb high levels of salts to be able to absorb the water across the intestine.

This project concerned the intestinal mechanism that marine eels use to absorb water. The possibilities that existed for the water absorption mechanism at the beginning of the project were that water could either go through the cells on the internal surface of the intestine or between those cells or via both routes.

In 1991 Dr Agre discovered water channel proteins (for which he won the Nobel prize), which he called "aquaporins", that let water into or out of cells depending on the level of water in each place. My laboratory identified eleven different kinds of aquaporin water channel proteins in eels. One of these in particular, called aquaporin1a, increases dramatically in the intestine when eels are transferred into seawater, suggesting that it might be involved in the water absorption process. At the beginning of this project it was unknown whether aquaporin1a was actually involved, as the evidence was only correlative, or if other aquaporin types were also involved. One key indicator of the involvement of aquaporins in the eel's intestinal water absorption mechanism was that the different aquaporin types would need to be in the correct (internal intestinal surface) cells to be able to be involved. So antibodies were raised that could bind to and detect each of the different eel aquaporin types in tissue slices through the intestine, studied using a microscope. Although all of the aquaporin types are produced in cells in different parts of the intestine, only a selection of these were shown to be produced by 'internal surface' cells. One type, aquaporin3b, is only found in a cell type unlikely to be involved in water absorption as it is involved in producing mucus. Further types, aquaporin4, 9a and 10b are also present at low levels in intestinal 'internal surface' cells. Lastly two aquaporins, numbered 8aa and 8ab are both found at higher levels in 'internal surface' cells all along the intestine and increase in amount after 3 weeks in seawater. In particular, aquaporin 8ab is often found in the sides of the surface cells (Image1), whereas aquaporin1a is in the cell's 'top' surface that immediately faces the fluid inside the intestine (Image2). The possibility exists that water flows from the inside of the intestine through aquaporin1a into the internal surface cells and out through aquaporin8ab into body fluids inside the eel (Image3). However again the location of these aquaporins only correlates with a mechanism involving water flow through the cells and does not prove this happens.

A central part of the project therefore involved finding a way to demonstrate the involvement of aquaporins' in the eel's intestinal water absorption mechanism. Often protein inhibitors would be used for this kind of study, which would block the proteins work and if they were involved in water absorption, lower the amount of that occurring. However with aquaporins there are no known specific inhibitors for these proteins, so a more difficult method was used (involving the use of chemicals called vivo-morpholinos that reduce the production of the protein from a particular gene), that had never been performed before in eels.
